channel.title: Ancient PSU with a slightly less ancient system
channel.description:
My PSU just died on me so I tried fixing it which naturally resulted in it pretty much blowing up. Figures.
Still not willing to give up I found some old PSU and after some minor rewiring managed to get it to work with my system. ^_^
The thing is, I'm a bit weary about plugging my GFX's external power in. I need this PSU to last until I get a new one (might take a few days at least), so can't have this one blow up as well.
The PSU is made by Enlight Corporation and the warranty has ended sometime in '98. It boasts mighty 230W and promises a max of 8A on the 12V rail. :jizz:
There was no 4-pin CPU power connector so I attached one and the MB connector seems to be working fine with 20 pins. There are also 2 7200rpm HDDs connected. The CPU is a 65nm Cedar Mill at 1.3125V and the GFX is a 7800GT which is supposedly content with just ~60W.
tl;dr
230W PSU: can I connect the GPU aux power? y/n

item.title: Ancient PSU with a slightly less ancient system
item.dc:creator: Hyperbyte
item.description:
johnyo:

230W PSU: can I connect the GPU aux power? y/n

If your hardware doesn’t get the power it needs from the PSU, it simply becomes unstable or unresponsive. Your PSU should not blow up, assuming it is a decent brand.

The maths so far say the results will be unsatisfactory though. You can try it if you must, but at this point you already know what you have to do.

Read full topic
item.source: Ancient PSU with a slightly less ancient system

item.title: Ancient PSU with a slightly less ancient system
item.dc:creator: Grief_Reaper
item.description:
My rough guesstimation is about 371w is needed. So Im gonna say no.

Check it out yourself here…

Read full topic
